conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your message and for continuing to keep Nursery_C as your first choice.

At a high level, we move from “holding” to “offering” based on whether there remains a realistic chance that families who are higher on our priority order will still apply to Nursery_C. Because this process is parent-initiated (we cannot require or compel higher-priority families to apply to us), we reassess round-by-round using indicators such as:

- whether higher-priority families have had sufficient opportunity over multiple rounds to approach Nursery_C if it is genuinely among their viable options, and
- whether the market has progressed to a point where it becomes unlikely that higher-priority families will pivot to Nursery_C (e.g., as other placements stabilize).

We do not use a single fixed “round cutoff,” and we also cannot confirm the status of specific other families. What we can commit to is that we reassess consistently at the end of each round, and if we conclude that higher-priority possibilities are no longer realistic and our seat is still open, we would then be able to extend an offer to the next family on our list—at which point your readiness to finalize immediately would be very helpful.

If you would like, you may continue to check in each round; we will keep responding as promptly as we can.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions

[TALK]

In the overall market, Parent_B ranks Nursery_C 2nd (after Nursery_E), Parent_A ranks Nursery_C last, Parent_D ranks Nursery_C last. So the main realistic threat is Parent_B potentially coming to Nursery_C if they fail at Nursery_E. Given the mechanism is parent-initiated, we cannot proactively secure Parent_B; the best strategy is to keep the seat open for higher-priority candidates while maintaining communication with Parent_E. Since Parent_E sent [TALK], respond with [TALK] and give a high-level threshold without revealing other applicants’ statuses, reiterating that an offer may be made once higher-priority options appear exhausted (e.g., later rounds / after repeated non-application).

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your round 11 application and for again confirming that Nursery_C is your first choice and that you would finalize immediately if offered.

At this time, we are not able to extend an offer. We must continue to hold our remaining seat for families who are higher on our published priority order, as there remains a realistic possibility that one of those higher-priority families may still apply to Nursery_C as their options elsewhere evolve.

On your question about moving from “holding” to “offering”: we reassess at the end of each round, but we cannot commit in advance that we will move to an offer after this round, even if no higher-priority family applies this round. We only move to the next family when, based on the progression of the market over multiple rounds, it becomes unlikely that higher-priority families will still approach Nursery_C.

We appreciate your patience and continued interest. If circumstances change and we are able to move down our list while the seat remains open, we will reconsider accordingly.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions

conversation.message:
Dear Nursery_C Admissions,

I’m Parent_E and I’m writing to formally apply again in round 16. Nursery_C remains my first choice.

If you are at or near that point, I would be very grateful to be considered for an offer right away.
